Tucson still remains stiff and rigid.  Tail thrashing the ground as he cont=
inues to listen to the old dragons air of caution.

" Then you shall step n=
o further.  I will meet with Archane but he is not to lay harm on my childr=
en or my wife.  He meets with me outside the cave and nowhere within it.  V=
iolate my demands and there will be consequences.  I do not trust you or an=
y stranger who assumes they can just drop in unannounced.  The old dragon w=
as wise not to trust you.  Something about you makes me rather unsettled.  =
Now go, give him that message and bother me no more until I ask for you."

=
He recedes back into the cave, with a growl of warning.  Immediately, he re=
joins Talon and his babies, reassuring them all with gentile snout rubs to =
all of them.  Again he could not help but cradle his offspring in his front=
 paws, and give them both a gentile kiss on the head.  He then keeps an eye=
 at the foot of the cave.  He keeps his word as parental instincts kick in.=


Local artist who specializes in illustration, using traditional and digit=
al media.  

I also specialize in hand made crafts.  Great for any occasion=
!  

Need a great gift idea that is original?  No problem!  Email me at thi=
s address and we will talk.  

On Jul 2, 2012, at 2:21 PM, Super Cyclonus <=
supercyclonus@...> wrote:

> DISCIPLE stepped back from TUCSON, altho=
ugh there is no fear in his
> face nor his demeanor, but it is a gesture of=
 respect.
> 
> "Ahh yes, old one I still see you in there." There is a nod =
from
> DISCIPLE. "Tucson, if indeed there is anything left of the old drago=
n
> within you then he would recognize me."
> 
> And indeed there is sense =
of grudging trust from the remnants of the
> ancient dragon within TUCSON a=
lthough TUCSON could choose to ignore it
> if he liked.
> 
> "I have come n=
ot to challenge you within your rookery." DISCIPLE said.
> "But Arcane, the=
 most ancient of all dragons living would cast his
> eyes on the one to who=
m the old one has committed his A'ja."
> 
> TUSCSON may get the jist of tha=
t last word A'ja from his connection to
> the old one, it is ancient dracon=
ic for dragon's breath. However not
> as a mode of attack. The dragons felt=
 that their power and even their
> life came from their breath, and when th=
ey died and took their last
> breath, their A'ja was set free.
> 
> (TAG)
>=
 
> - Preston
>

ther me no more until I ask for you."</div><div><br></div><div>He recedes b=
ack into the cave, with a growl of warning.  Immediately, he rejoins T=

n>



    <div id=3D"ygrp-text">
      
      
      <p>DISCIPLE stepped ba=
ck from TUCSON, although there is no fear in his<br>
face nor his demeanor,=
 but it is a gesture of respect.<br>
<br>
"Ahh yes, old one I still see you=
 in there." There is a nod from<br>
DISCIPLE. "Tucson, if indeed there is a=
nything left of the old dragon<br>
within you then he would recognize me."<=
br>
<br>
And indeed there is sense of grudging trust from the remnants of t=
he<br>
ancient dragon within TUCSON although TUCSON could choose to ignore =
it<br>
if he liked.<br>
<br>
"I have come not to challenge you within your =
rookery." DISCIPLE said.<br>
"But Arcane, the most ancient of all dragons l=
iving would cast his<br>
eyes on the one to whom the old one has committed =
his A'ja."<br>
<br>
TUSCSON may get the jist of that last word A'ja from hi=
s connection to<br>
the old one, it is ancient draconic for dragon's breath=
. However not<br>
as a mode of attack. The dragons felt that their power an=
d even their<br>
life came from their breath, and when they died and took t=
heir last<br>
breath, their A'ja was set free.<br>
<br>
(TAG)<br>
<br>
- Pr=
eston<br>
</p>
